1 Introduction

Risks and health effects from Diesel vehicles and machines emissions have for long been known. These are actually the main motivating for their reduction in several countries, given their intensive use. Research shows that thousands of deaths can be related to air pollution every year, reducing the average life expectancy by up to one year [1].

The use of oxygenated blends, with a lower proportion of aromatic hydrocarbons and sulfur in their composition, leads to a reduction in the amount and size of particles emitted by the exhaust systems [2]. If a long -term policy is implemented to gradually reduce this type of emissio n, there may be a decline in the annual trend of deaths from respiratory and cardiovascular diseases [3]. Replacing some content of diesel for biofuels (like biodiesel or bioetanol) is the simplest way for the transportation sector to begin to move to a mo re sustainable lifecycle. This action is lined up with the “17 UN Sustainable Development Goals” shown in Fig.1, which was released in September 2015 after a meeting of more than 150 world leaders at UN headquarters took place. At the time, they formally a dopted a new sustainable development agenda to be pursued by 2030.
Fig. 1 . United Nations Sustainable Development Goals 2030 (source: UN website)

Its 13th goal is to “Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts by regulating emissions an d promoting developments in renewable energy” by reducing greenhouse gases emissions (CO 2, CH 4 and N 2O) that have reached unparalleled levels in human history and so trying not to exceed the global temperature by 2 °C above pre -industrial levels - the targ et set by the governments.

The idea of developing this research was born in order to give a contribution to the fight against climate change. Through the production and analysis of diesel -biodiesel -ethanol blend s, its main goal is to find the one(s) that meet the current Brazilian Oil Agency (Agência Nacional do Petróleo, ANP) specification and, therefore, to allow its use in Diesel engines, widely deployed in the national fleet of trucks, buses and some light vehicles.
2 Raw materials

Diesel fuel is defined as a fractional distillate of petroleum fuel oil consisting of from 10 to 25 carbon atoms, with a distillation range commonly between 150 °C and 400 °C, which presents a set of properties that allows its adequate use mainly in vehicl es powered by engines that run on the Diesel cycle. It stands out as the most used fuel in Brazil, notably in the road sector, due to its transportation system [4].

The Diesel fuel sold in Brazil gets an addition of biodiesel following according to a feder al law defined and regulated by the National Agency of Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels (ANP). The current percentage as of May 2021 is 10%.

Biodiesel is a renewable form of diesel fuel obtained from the transesterification of triglycerides, which are p resent in oils (soy, palm, cotton, etc.), vegetable and animal fats, with a primary alcohol, methanol (the most currently used) or ethanol, generating two products, the ester and the glycerin. Fig. 3 shows the most common raw materials for biodiesel produc tion in Brazil. After undergoing purification processes to fit the quality specification it can be sold as biodiesel.
Fig. 2 . Most commonly raw materials used in the production of biodiesel in Brazil (source: ANP, 2019)
In Brazil, its blend with petrodiesel started in 2004 on an experimental basis and, between 2005 and 2007, a 2% addition became voluntary. In January 2008 it then became officially mandatory.

Ethanol is an organic chemical compound with the molecular formula C 2H6O produced mainly by yeasts from fermentable sugars. In Brazil and in the world, it is widely used in spark ignition engines (Otto cycle) to fully or partially replace gasoline, as the latter is a fossil fuel. In Brazil two forms of ethanol are deployed: in its anhydrous for m as an additive for gasoline fuel or in its hydrated form, sold throughout the country as a regular engine fuel [5].
3 Economic aspects

Domestic diesel consumption is a good thermometer of Brazilian economy. Due to its large use in the national fleet of t rucks for transporting goods throughout the country, both are closely bonded. In the last five years both remained stagnant, with only minor growth, of only 1,4%, 2017 - 2018 period concerned.

A resurgence of consumption – and thus an increase of diesel cons umption – may as well lead to an increase of the production / consumption of anhydrous ethanol if, as suggested in this paper, the biofuel is added to diesel fuel. This addition is also a way of promoting / stimulating the processing, for example, of sugar cane bagasse – a major unwanted byproduct with no apparent destination – as a raw material for the second -generation ethanol to supply an increase of demand that is to be created.

If we now look at the share of imports in diesel sales, it is even more noti ceable the need to seek a replacement to reduce external dependence. Imports have been growing strongly, nowadays they are above 20%, as shown in Fig.3.
Fig. 3 . Share of imports in Brazilian diesel sales (source: ANP, 2019)
4 Environmental aspects

According to studies, the use of biodiesel and oxygenated fuels shows an effective reduction in emissions of regulated gases (HC, PM and CO), automatically improving well -being and life quality of a community. The burning of biodiesel compared to that of d iesel also forms less soot, since biodiesel does not have aromatic compounds which, in general, suffer incomplete combustion [6]. Another fact that allows biodiesel to burn producing less soot is its ester group. It is more likely that biodiesel will produ ce a cleaner burn, resulting in carbon dioxide and water. This is a remarkable characteristic of biodiesel regarding air quality in large cities, since soot is largely composed of polyaromatic substances, with enormous carcinogenic potential [7]. In additi on, the use of biofuels has a positive performance in the control of greenhouse gases, especially CO 2 (carbon dioxide). All the carbon generated in sugarcane crops, from cultivation to its transformation, is reabsorbed by a new one, representing an effecti ve reduction in relation to the use of fossil fuels [8].
5 Social aspects

The sugarcane and biodiesel industries together respond for more than one million direct jobs in Brazil (2018). There are about 800 thousand jobs in the sugar and alcohol sector and more than 200 thousand in the biodiesel industry according to the Center for Advanced Studies in Applied Economics (Cepea) of the University of São Paulo (USP) and the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA). If indirect jobs are added to this number (e. g. companies that provide products and services to these sectors) about 1.5 million jobs are reached.

In the next decade, the volumes of both ethanol and biodiesel produced are expected to double, ethanol from 27.8 to 47.1 billion liters and biodiesel from 5.4 to 11.1 billion liters [9]. According to UNICANA (sugarcane producers union), a production plant with a 500 million liter per year installed capacity can generate up to 8,500 direct and indirect jobs combined and an increase of just 1% in the blend of biodiesel in petrodiesel can generate up to 20 thousand jobs. The commercial use of biodiesel -ethanol -petrodiesel blend s would promote a huge social benefit, it would demand qualified workers, highly trained in administrative, chemical, agricultural and production areas Thousands of jobs would be kept away from major urban centers, taking progress to these locations and reducing public spending on infrastructure in large cities.
6 Materials and Methods
6.1 Raw materials

The raw materials used in the development of the work are the ones that follow, Fig. 4 shows them. • Diesel fuel S10 produced at Petrobras' Paraná Refinery (REPAR) which meets the quality specifications established in ANP Resolution 65; • Anhydrous ethanol (EAC, 99.8% purity) Isofar br and, which meets the quality specifications established in ANP Resolution 19; • Biodiesel produced at the Petrobras Biocombustíveis (PBio) plant located in Montes Claros (MG) from a blend of soybean oil and beef tallow that meets the specifications contain ed in ANP Resolution
Fig. 4 . Raw materials (source: author)
6.2 Blend s production

In order to evaluate the influence ethanol addition on the physical -chemical properties of diesel -biodiesel blend s, several blend s were formulated and characterized, all on a volumetric basis. First, diesel -biodiesel (BX) blend s were produced with 10%, 15% and 20% of biodiesel. These particular concentrations were chosen because 10% content of biodiesel was being added to petrodiesel when the studies were carried out; 15% was expected to be reached by 2023 according to the government official plans and 20% was an estimate content to be assumed in a near future.

From each BX generated, blend s with 10% and 15% of ethanol were produced, accounting for a total of nine blend s, as shown in Fig. 5. Ethanol contents were selected considering results already described in the literature, where blend s with 2% of biodiesel and 8% of ethanol attained the quality specifications [10].
Fig. 5 . Blends produced for the study (source: au thor)

Physical -chemical analysis carried out (source: author) For the lubricity study , a wear test originally intended for lubricants was adapted and used, the ASTM D4172, known as “Four -ball wear test”. T hree aligned balls are kept fixed and soaked in the sample . The upper ball rotates and is in contact against the lower three balls , as may be seen in Fig. 6 . Time, temperature, rotation and load are controlled and, in the end, the diameters of the grooves ("scars", also shown Fig. 6) formed by the friction are measured with a profilometer or microscope. For the stability study, three scenarios were set. 7 Results and discussion
7.1 Physical -chemical characterization

The r esults for the physical -chemical characterization are shown in table 2 . As observed, with the addition of ethanol the parameter that changed the most was the flash point. Both contents of 10% and 15% made it go under the specification value, 38 ºC minimum . For this reason, blend s with 15% of ethanol were put aside and the eva luation continued only with blend s of 10%, even if it is already known that those do not meet this quality requirement either , reaching only 30 ºC of flash point . So, regarding the current quality specification for diesel fuel, it would be necessary to add ethanol contents below 10% in order to guarantee an attainment of the specification.

Also because of the addition of ethanol, distillation showed an “early boiling front”, meaning that the blends initial boiling point (IBP) was detected before that of a regular diesel. However, as only some specific points are standardized (and IBP is not one of them), the blends made it to attend the specification values.

The oxidation stability of the blend s also decreases, but it can be solved by adding antioxidation additives. The other parameters showed slight or no variations and were within the limits of the specification . Param . Spec. B100 Diesel B10 B15 B20 B10 Flash Specific Gravity.

7.2 Lubricity study
The following table 3 s hows the results of the wear scars observed after the tests were completed.

Sample Result, mm Diesel 1,30 Biodiesel 0,37 Table 3 . Wear scars observed after the completion of the test (source: author) From the results it can be inferred that an increase in the biodiesel content leads to a smaller scar diameter observed on the microscope and, therefore, better lubricity properties. The opposite is observed with the introduction of ethanol. With the incre ase in alcohol content, there is an increase in the scar diameter, therefore greater wear. However, due to the beneficial effect of biodiesel, none of the evaluated blends showed a wear scar diameter greater than the one caused by diesel fuel (1.30 mm). It is also important to not ice that the low lubricity of this diesel fuel is related to the low sulfur content (10 mg/kg).

It is known that the addition of ethanol to diesel reduces its viscosity and, consequently, its lubricating properties . Field and lab dynamometer tests have shown that blends of diesel and ethanol should not be used in engines whose injection system is performed by rotary pumps [11]. Lubricity improvers are mainly fatty acids, esters and amides, some times in an aromatic solvent, which have affinity for metallic surfaces, being called then surface -active compounds [12]. A film is formed on the surface and avoids metal -to-metal contact, which could cause wear and rupture under light and moderate loads. Cont ents of 0.1% to 1% are usually enough to take lubricity to appropriate levels [13].
7.3 Stability study

As previously mentioned, stability tests were carried out only on blends with the lowest ethanol content (10%) due to the reduction of the flash point on those of greater contents . This study was performed to observe the behavior of the blends under different conditions, since there is a

remarkable polarity difference between ethanol and diesel. More than that, it was expected that the presence of biodie sel (component with an intermediate polarity) would contribute positively to the stability of these blends .

Sample Water content, t0, mg/kg 10 °C, 46% RU 22 °C, 52% RU No control time, days Wt content, mg/kg time, days Wt content, mg/kg time, days Wt content, mg/kg Table 4 . Stability tests results (source: author) An increase in biodiesel content, as expected, increases the amount of water solubilized in the sample , acting as a cosolvent. However, the hygroscopic properties of biodiesel contribute to a greater absorption of water from the environment, making blends with higher biodiesel content s stable only for an equal or smaller period if compared to those lower biodiesel content s. Fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) have been widely studied as additives to promot e diesel – ethanol blends . Patents worldwide [14][15][1 6] also describe the use of fatty acid esters of methyl, ethyl, cyclic or aromatic alcohols or even ethoxylated polyols to improve miscibility of diesel -ethanol blends. These studies show that the addition of 1 % to 2% in volume work to stabilize a blend of up to 15% of anhydrous etha nol in diesel , acting as cosolvents . Cosolvents are defined as organic solvents with good miscibility in polar substances and are used in formulations to improve the solubility of substances with low polarity, increasing the chemical stability of these blends. It includes, then, a variety of compounds with these properties. Its effect is due to intermolecular interactions established by the cosolvent at the same time with ethanol molecules and those of the hydrocarbons of diesel fuel, assuring the blend stability [17].

8 Conclusions

Biofuels are a sustainable option for the replacement of fossil fuels, which are largely used for transporting cargo and people in Brazil . Used in blends or as a whole, they can reduce particulate emissions and harmful gases that affect human health and life in general. In addition, with the development of the Brazilian biofuels market, thousands of direct and indirect jobs will be created , bringing wealth and progress to the country.

Particularly regarding sugarcane, the use of bagasse as a raw material in the production of second -generation ethanol will be positive in creating new jobs and in solving the problem that is the enormous growing mass es of by -product bagasse t hat is not used entirety in the generation of steam in the sugar and alcohol plants.

Ethanol -biodiesel -diesel blends formulated for this research proved to be viable for use in Diesel engines. The addition of ethanol and biodiesel to diesel does not affect negatively the specification at all. Important parameters such as viscosity, density, acid number , cetane number and cold filter plugging point remained within the ranges established or above the minimum required , exception for the flash point, what was already expected, given the low flash point of ethanol. The lubricity study showed that the presence of biodiesel in the blends improved the lubricating characteristics of the formulated fuels, what was, on the other hand, worsened ny the addition of ethan ol. There was a lubricity increase in relation to diesel fuel (decreasing the diameter of the wear scar formed ), which means less wear and friction between the surfaces of the fuel system .

Results for the stability study varied considerably, from reasonabl e to good, indicating caution when using fuel blends , as it is already done in relation to the CFPP in different regions of the country, at different periods throughout the year. A clear conclusion is that higher contents of biodiesel allow a larger absorp tion of water, proving its cosolvent character istic. However, due to its higher hygroscopic ity compared to petrod iesel, it ends up absorbing a greater amount of water from the surrounding environment, leading to a phase separation as well . In other words, the increase in the biodiesel content did not help increas ing phase stability of the blends .

Additional measures to mitigate the presence of water in the fuel (a critical factor for engine life) such as adding coalescence additives, installing desiccant ve nts and paying special attention to good storage and handling practices must be implemented.
